results.title: Bophana
results.brief_description: Bophana Audiovisual Resource Center in Cambodia is dedicated to the collection, digitisation and preservation of media lost during the Khmer Rouge reign, including newsreels, features, records, documentaries and photos.

constellations_primary.name: Bophana: cultural memory on film
constellations_primary.description: Bophana Audiovisual Resource Center is dedicated to the collection, preservation and presentation of audiovisual material related to Cambodia. Their collection includes archival footage, newsreels, documentaries, feature films, photographs and vinyl records.

results.description:
Bophana Audiovisual Resource Center in Cambodia is dedicated to the collection, digitisation and preservation of media lost during the Khmer Rouge reign, including newsreels, features, records, documentaries and photos. The 1960s and early 70s were a golden age for Cambodian cinema. The thriving film industry produced over 300 films and cinemas dotted the country alongside a vibrant music scene and traditional ballet. When the Khmer Rouge took over in 1975, artists were targeted and a key aspect of Cambodia’s cultural heritage was dismantled. Safeguarding this material is essential for reconstructing Cambodia’s cultural memory, allowing for new interpretations of historical footage and giving agency back to the community.

An institutional partnership between ACMI, Bophana and Cambodian Living Arts is supported by the Australian Government through the Australia-ASEAN Council of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade
description_for_label:
Bophana Audiovisual Resource Center in Cambodia is dedicated to the collection, digitisation and preservation of media lost during the Khmer Rouge reign, including newsreels, features, records, documentaries and photos. The 1960s and early 70s were a golden age for Cambodian cinema. The thriving film industry produced over 300 films and cinemas dotted the country alongside a vibrant music scene and traditional ballet. When the Khmer Rouge took over in 1975, artists were targeted and a key aspect of Cambodia’s cultural heritage was dismantled. Safeguarding this material is essential for reconstructing Cambodia’s cultural memory, allowing for new interpretations of historical footage and giving agency back to the community.

An institutional partnership between ACMI, Bophana and Cambodian Living Arts is supported by the Australian Government through the Australia-ASEAN Council of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade

results.title: Bootmen [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Hilary Linstead and Dein Perry
results.brief_description: Loosely based on director Dein Perry’s early life as a dancer, “Bootmen” is the story of two brothers - Sean (Adam Garcia) and Mitchell (Sam Worthington) - working in a steel mill in the industrial city of Newcastle. Both dream of one day escaping from the mill, Sean as a tap dancer in Sydney and Mitchell purchasing a tow truck to get out of the only life their stern father has ever known. Tension arrises between the brothers when Sean quits the mill to go to Sydney to study with a well known dance troupe and Mitchell moves in on Sean’s woman, Linda (Sophie Lee), both brothers finding themselves in love with her. “Bootmen” is a feel-good movie that is similar in genre to “Strictly Ballroom” and “The Full Monty”, a touching and sweet film with wonderful tap dancing sequences. Cast also includes William Zappa, Richard Carter and Susie Porter.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Hilary Linstead and Dein Perry

results.title: Boothlite
results.brief_description:
Video recording filmed by artists at Swinburne University as they complete the construction of ‘Boothlite’, an interactive multimedia installation. ‘Boothlite’ exhibited in 1996 in a collection of installations, footage of which appears in the video without title. A steel, rubber and perspex booth for one, ‘Boothlite’ features both an internal and external monitor. The internal monitor and keyboard allow the spectator to interact with a series of digital images and sequences; the external monitor invites those outside ‘Boothlite’ to go inside. In the video, the various artists involved discuss the work and battle against a sleepless block of 48 or more hours in order to get it finished in time for installation.

James Verdon is one of the artists who originally created a work know as ‘the Booth’. The Booth is a mini cinema which Cinemedia has commissioned James and others to build.

results.title: Booom (K)
results.creator_credit: Kratky Film, Kamil Pixa, Peter Hollander and Bratislav Pojar
results.brief_description: An animated film taking a humorous look at a very serious subject: the global arms race. Looks at the history of aggression from caveman times to atomic missiles and the theory that might makes right.

results.brief_description: An animation in which satirist Jules Feiffer makes a pungent comment on the US arms race and military build-up. Text by Jules Feiffer, animation by Bill Plympton.

results.title: Boomsville
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Robert Verrall and Yvon Mallette
results.brief_description: An amusing diagnosis of big city growing pains. This film is an ironic view of town planning or rather, the lack of it and what has happened to our cities as a result. Done in cartoon animation, the film traces the growth of the typical city, from a tiny settlement in the vast North American wilderness to the car-clogged metropolis that so many cities are today. Awards: New York; Oberhousen; Les Menuires.

results.title: Boomerang = Bumerang
results.brief_description: Cartoon in which a butterfly causes trouble at a rocket station. This film is a satire on a military dictatorship and the perseverance of the human spirit. The soundtrack contains no music or dialogue, only sound effects. Animated by Branislav Nemet and Turido Paus.

results.title: Boomerang (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and Frank L. Few
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Demonstrates how the aborigine crafts the boomerang. The diligent search for the exact right piece of wood, the burning off of the outer bark, the tedious, laborious whittling with a sharpended stone and the fashioning of the slight twist at each end to git it its unique quality of returning to its point of departure. Introduced by Bill Onus.
